title: 114_s2946
content: The Act titled "Law Enforcement Officers Equity Act" includes certain positions within the definition of law enforcement officer for retirement purposes. The "Law Enforcement Officers Equity Act" amends the Federal Employees Retirement System to include employees whose duties involve investigating or apprehending individuals suspected of criminal offenses and who are authorized to carry a firearm. Employees authorized to carry firearms include those from the Internal Revenue Service, United States Postal Inspection Service, Department of Veterans Affairs, and U.S. Customs and Border Protection. The amendments in this section apply to individuals appointed as law enforcement officers, whose duties involve the custody, management, and disposition of seized and forfeited property. The amendments in this section apply to individuals appointed as law enforcement officers, defined in title 5, United States Code, on or after the date of enactment of this Act, and consistent with the requirements of section 3. The amendments in this section apply to individuals appointed as law enforcement officers, defined in title 5, United States Code, on or after the date of enactment of this Act. Definitions in this section include the Director of the Office of Personnel Management, the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund, incumbents as individuals appointed as law enforcement officers before and serving on the date of enactment, law enforcement officers meeting specific requirements, and prior service for incumbents making an election. Service performed by an incumbent before or after the date of enactment of this Act shall be treated as service performed as a law enforcement officer. An incumbent can make an election to continue as a law enforcement officer by submitting a written request to the Director within 5 years of the enactment of the Act or before separating from service. They can also pay a deposit for prior service performed to the Fund. An incumbent can continue as a law enforcement officer by paying a deposit for prior service to the Fund, including interest on the deducted amount. If the full deposit is not paid, all prior service is affected. An incumbent can maintain credit for prior service as a law enforcement officer by paying a deposit to the Fund. The resulting annuity will be reduced in a similar manner as described in title 5, United States Code, to make up any unpaid amounts. If an incumbent elects to do so, the agency that employed them during prior service must remit an amount to the Director for deposit in the Fund. The incumbent can maintain credit for prior service as a law enforcement officer by paying a deposit to the Fund. The total amount of Government contributions under section 8334 or 8423 of title 5, United States Code, along with interest, must be computed in accordance with regulations. Contributions are to be made ratably. The Director shall prescribe regulations for government contributions on behalf of an incumbent over a 10-year period. Law enforcement officers are exempt from mandatory separation for 3 years after the enactment of this Act. Regulations will also cover survivor annuity entitlements. (g) Rule of Construction.--This section does not apply to reemployed annuitants.
